subject: Re: [junit] JUNIT :How to make it Data Driven
msgSnippet: ... Yup, that s why @DataProviders are useful:  not only can you declare your test methods with parameters, you can actually write a Java method that will
messageBody:
On 3/1/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
>
> If you're committed to using Excel, your first order of business is
> probably making sure you know how to interface between Excel and Java,
> before worrying at all about JUnit. Good luck,


Yup, that's why @DataProviders are useful: not only can you declare your
test methods with parameters, you can actually write a Java method that will
create these parameters for you, so they can come from pretty much anywhere
(Excel, text, XML, database, network, etc...)

Documentation can be found here:

http://testng.org/doc/documentation-main.html#parameters-dataproviders
<http://www.google.com/url?sa=D&q=http%3A%2F%2Ftestng.org%2Fdoc%2Fdocumentation-main.html%23parameters-dataproviders>

--
Cédric


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
